conclusion: The capacitor has a constant voltage V, the distance between the plates is d, and a metal plate of thickness l is placed on the lower plate. The particle P is stationary initially.

When the metal plate is in place, the effective separation between the active plates is d - l. The electric field E1 between the plates is E1 = V / (d - l). The force on the charged particle q is F1 = qE1.
Initially, the particle is at rest, so the forces are balanced: qE1 = mg. Substituting E1: q(V / (d - l)) = mg.
When the metal plate is removed, the separation between the plates is now d. The new electric field E2 is E2 = V / d. The new force on the particle is F2 = qE2.
The forces acting on the particle are now the electric force F2 and gravity mg. The net force F_net is F_net = qE2 - mg. Using E2 = V / d: F_net = q(V / d) - mg.
From the initial balance q(V / (d - l)) = mg, we have qV = mg(d - l). Substitute qV = mg(d - l) into F_net: F_net = mg((d - l) / d) - mg.
Simplifying F_net: F_net = mg((d - l - d) / d) = mg(-l / d).
Using Newton's second law F_net = ma: ma = mg(l / d). Solving for a: a = g(l / d).
The acceleration of the particle P when the metal plate is removed is a = (lg) / d.
